message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has sustained a gunshot wound to the right thigh and has a diminished pedal pulse. Duplex ultrasonography is a noninvasive test that can be used to assess for vascular injury and is the most appropriate next step in management. Wound cleaning and tetanus toxoid should also be given, but this is not the most appropriate next step in management. Fasciotomy is not indicated at this time as compartment syndrome has not been diagnosed. Digital subtraction angiography is an invasive test and is not the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has sustained a gunshot wound to the thigh and has diminished pedal pulse on the right side, which suggests possible vascular injury. Duplex ultrasonography can be used to evaluate for vascular injury and is the most appropriate next step in management. Wound cleaning and tetanus toxoid should also be performed, but they do not address the potential vascular injury. Fasciotomy and digital subtraction angiography may be indicated if there is evidence of compartment syndrome or significant vascular injury on duplex ultrasonography.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gunshot wound and diminished pedal pulse indicate a possible vascular injury. Duplex ultrasonography is a non-invasive diagnostic test that can be used to assess vascular injury and guide further management. Wound cleaning and tetanus toxoid should also be administered, but further management should be guided by the results of the ultrasound. Fasciotomy and digital subtraction angiography are more invasive and would not be appropriate as initial management steps.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with a gunshot wound to the thigh and diminished pedal pulse on the right side, which suggests arterial injury. The most appropriate next step in management would be duplex ultrasonography to evaluate for arterial injury as it is a non-invasive option that can assess blood flow to the leg and help guide further management. Wound cleaning and tetanus toxoid are standard procedures for any wound, and fasciotomy is indicated if there is a suspected or confirmed compartment syndrome. Digital subtraction angiography is an invasive procedure and is not the first line of management for suspected arterial injury.

The patient has sustained a gunshot wound to the right thigh and has a diminished pedal pulse on the right side compared to the left, which suggests possible vascular injury. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a Duplex ultrasonography to assess for arterial or venous injury. Wound cleaning and tetanus toxoid should be done initially, but are not the most appropriate next step given the possibility of vascular injury. Fasciotomy may be necessary if there is evidence of compartment syndrome, but is not indicated before further evaluation. Digital subtraction angiography may also be useful, but is less commonly used than Duplex ultrasonography.
